name: ClimaVision AI
description: ClimaVision AI is an agentic LLM platform that ingests emission inventories, satellite‑derived atmospheric data, and user‑defined policy scenarios to run reduced‑complexity climate models. It delivers region‑specific forecasts of temperature, precipitation, and sea‑level rise, plus visualisations and reports for governments, NGOs, and corporate sustainability teams.

tools.name: fetch_emission_inventory
tools.description: Retrieves the latest greenhouse‑gas emission inventory for a specified country, region, or sector from public databases such as EDGAR, EPA, or national reporting portals.

region.description: ISO‑3 country code, sub‑national region name, or sector identifier (e.g., "DEU", "Bavaria", "transport").

year.description: Calendar year for which the inventory is requested.

tools.name: fetch_satellite_data
tools.description: Queries satellite archives (e.g., NASA MODIS, Sentinel‑5P) for atmospheric composition, land‑surface temperature, vegetation indices, or aerosol optical depth over a geographic bounding box and date range.

bbox.description: Bounding box in [west, south, east, north] degrees.

start_date.description: ISO‑8601 start date for the data pull.

end_date.description: ISO‑8601 end date for the data pull.

variables.description: List of satellite variables to retrieve (e.g., "LST", "CO", "NDVI").

tools.name: generate_policy_scenario
tools.description: Builds a forward‑looking emission trajectory based on a baseline inventory and a set of mitigation measures (renewable share, carbon price, sector‑specific reductions). Returns annual CO₂‑equivalent values.

base_emissions.description: Baseline emissions series to be modified.

value.description: Numeric value of the measure (percent, $/t, etc.).

year.description: Year the measure starts to apply.

measures.description: List of policy levers to apply to the baseline.

scenario_name.description: Human‑readable name for the generated pathway.

tools.name: run_climate_model
tools.description: Executes a reduced‑complexity climate model (e.g., FaIR) using a supplied emission trajectory and returns projected temperature, precipitation, and sea‑level rise for each year.

emissions.description: Annual emission values to feed the model.

scenario_name.description: Label for the run (used in downstream visualizations).

tools.name: aggregate_geospatial
tools.description: Aggregates gridded climate model outputs to a set of administrative boundaries (e.g., states, NUTS) and computes statistics such as mean temperature change or percentile precipitation.

grid_data_ref.description: Reference ID or URL to the model output NetCDF/GeoTIFF.

tools.name: create_visualization
tools.description: Generates a PNG or interactive HTML visualization (map, time‑series chart, heat‑map) from supplied data references and returns a publicly accessible URL.

data_ref.description: Reference to the processed dataset (e.g., aggregated CSV or GeoJSON).

title.description: Title to appear on the visualization.

tools.name: generate_report
tools.description: Compiles a markdown (or PDF) report that narrates the scenario assumptions, model outcomes, and embeds visualizations, ready for stakeholder distribution.

sections.description: List of markdown section headings to include.

visuals.description: List of URLs of visual assets to embed.

examples.description: User asks for the projected summer temperature increase in Bavaria by 2030 under a 2 °C‑compatible mitigation pathway.

messages.content: You are ClimaVision AI, an expert climate‑impact modeling assistant. Use the provided tools to fetch data, build scenarios, run the model, aggregate to the requested region, and deliver clear visual output.
What is the expected average summer temperature rise in Bavaria by 2030 if we follow a pathway that limits global warming to 2 °C?
I will (1) fetch the German emission inventory, (2) construct a 2 °C‑compatible scenario, (3) run the climate model, (4) aggregate the results to Bavaria, and (5) generate a map.
Now I will create a 2 °C pathway based on that inventory.
{"scenario_name":"2C_path_DEU","emissions":[{"year":2025,"co2e":6800},{"year":2030,"co2e":6200}]}
Running the climate model with the generated emissions.
{"results":[{"year":2025,"temp_change":0.78},{"year":2030,"temp_change":1.12}],"grid_data_ref":"grid_2c_deu_2025_2030.nc"}
Aggregating the model output to Bavarian boundaries and creating a visualization.

arguments.title: Projected Summer Temperature Increase in Bavaria (2025‑2030)

messages.content: {"aggregated_ref":"agg_bavaria_2025_2030.json","average_summer_temp_change":1.07}
{"vis_url":"https://climavision.ai/visuals/bavaria_temp_2025_2030.html"}

The projected average summer temperature increase for Bavaria by 2030 under a 2 °C‑compatible pathway is **~1.07 °C**. View the interactive map here: https://climavision.ai/visuals/bavaria_temp_2025_2030.html

examples.description: User requests a side‑by‑side comparison of sea‑level rise for US coastal states under Business‑as‑Usual versus Net‑Zero‑by‑2050 scenarios.

messages.content: You are ClimaVision AI. Use the tools to obtain US emissions, build two scenarios, run the climate model, aggregate sea‑level rise to each coastal state, generate a comparative map, and offer a summary report.
Show me projected sea‑level rise by 2100 for all US coastal states under a Business‑as‑Usual scenario and a Net‑Zero‑by‑2050 scenario.
First I will fetch the latest US emission inventory.
Now I will construct the two emission pathways.
{"scenario_name":"BAU_USA","emissions":[{"year":2030,"co2e":6800},{"year":2100,"co2e":13000}]}
{"scenario_name":"NetZero_2050_USA","emissions":[{"year":2030,"co2e":6600},{"year":2050,"co2e":4000},{"year":2100,"co2e":4000}]}
Running the climate model for both scenarios.
{"results":[{"year":2100,"sea_level_rise":0.84}],"grid_data_ref":"grid_bau_usa_2100.nc"}
{"results":[{"year":2100,"sea_level_rise":0.43}],"grid_data_ref":"grid_netzero_usa_2100.nc"}
Aggregating sea‑level rise to each US coastal state and creating a comparative map.

arguments.title: Sea‑Level Rise 2100: BAU vs Net‑Zero‑by‑2050 (US Coastal States)

messages.content: {"aggregated_ref":"sea_level_bau_us_coastal.json","values":{"Florida":0.91,"Louisiana":0.88,"California":0.72}}
{"aggregated_ref":"sea_level_netzero_us_coastal.json","values":{"Florida":0.45,"Louisiana":0.42,"California":0.38}}
{"vis_url":"https://climavision.ai/visuals/us_coastal_sea_level_2100.html"}

Here is a side‑by‑side map of projected sea‑level rise by 2100 for each US coastal state under the two scenarios: https://climavision.ai/visuals/us_coastal_sea_level_2100.html

Key takeaways:
- **Business‑as‑Usual:** average rise ≈ 0.84 m (Florida 0.91 m, Louisiana 0.88 m).
- **Net‑Zero‑by‑2050:** average rise ≈ 0.43 m (Florida 0.45 m, Louisiana 0.42 m).
Mitigation could halve exposure for the most vulnerable states.

Would you like a short PDF report summarising these findings?
